if more closely matches the rhetoric

this is not the first time that these

initially had a kind of trial by fire in

the question of extensions of

like that process was repeating itself
now it seems like it's not we seem to
have stalemate at this point there's a
couple of different options it looks
like 44 how these folks might move
forward the president continues to say
that he's willing to have some sort of a
grand grander bargain that would cut
more like in the neighborhood of four
trillion dollars the Republicans say
well that's too much we're not willing
to do that there's those two options a
big plan or a scaled-back plan neither
of those though look like it has much
support in the house there's a third
option out there the Senate Republican
leader Mitch McConnell has thrown out
this idea that perhaps if there isn't a
deal to be reached that the way to go is
to simply say look let the president go
ahead and raise the debt ceiling but
essentially it would be handing off the
responsibility but also the
accountability for doing it to the
president and then come back at these
questions of debt reduction and deficit

programs at a different time essentially
d couple those issues that is being
interpreted in a lot of quarters as a

that the possibility of a default the
possibility of a failure to raise the

if that were to happen the Republican
Party might be more seen as more to
blame and so he's looking for a way out
it remains to be seen exactly which path
the negotiators take and it'll be kind
of nail-biting time soon enough globally
we raised more than eighty six million

in terms of fundraising is Mitt Romney
he's only raised about 18 million

better than any of his competitors for
the Republican nomination all of whom
are under 5 million but it's not enough
